page.title: 13Customs in Upton.
page.content: {Oak Apple day,}29th May, celebrates the restoration of the monarchy, the date on which Charles 11 landed back in this country in 1660. Parliament decreed that this date should be a national holiday but this was repealed in 1830. In Upton this day was celebrated by people wearing button holes of Oak Apple leaves and dancing in the streets.These celebrations had ceased by the time of the second world war. In 1985 these celebrations were resumed taking place on May 25th the Saturday of the Spring Bank holiday weekend. Wearing Oak Apple leaves children from the Junior School danced first, followed by the adults who ended their dance at the Memorial Hall where lunch was served.
